abstract.p: Nelson Marans letter notes that while voice recognition technology may be cost efficient for customer relations departments, certain people will have difficult time with it and become frustrated, causing companies to lose customers (Sept 9 article)

block.p: Re ''At Your Service (Or Wit's End)'' (Sept. 9) : While there may be a substantial cost saving for the corporation by not having a live person answer the phone, using instead recognition by computer driven technology, the downside for the consumer and ultimately for the company may overwhelm the advantages.

Re ''At Your Service (Or Wit's End)'' (Sept. 9) : While there may be a substantial cost saving for the corporation by not having a live person answer the phone, using instead recognition by computer driven technology, the downside for the consumer and ultimately for the company may overwhelm the advantages.
There are at least three classes of customers who may be put off by the technology.
First, for those with English as a second language, the intonations may not be addressed properly.
Second, for the elderly used to talking to an individual, the lack of human communication may be a turnoff.
Finally, for soft-spoken individuals, I have found that both verbal and numerical responses many times are misinterpreted and noted incorrectly by the equipment.
When a customer or a potential customer becomes frustrated, the automatic reaction is to never deal with that company again.
